DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indication of embedding material used in processing cells or tissue prior to storage.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Cleaning and preparation of tissues for further use in biological products._To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination._A substance holding another substance in solution or suspension.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Cleaning and preparation of tissues for further use in biological products.

Concepts.definition: Cleaning and preparation of tissues for further use in biological products.

Property.preferredDefinition: To surround a pathological or histological specimen with a firm and sometimes hard medium such as paraffin, wax, celloidin, or a resin, in order to make possible the cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination. (On-line Medical Dictionary):A substance holding another substance in solution or suspension.

Concepts.definition: To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination.
A substance holding another substance in solution or suspension.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Concepts linked to Tissue Banking and Pathology activities

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 10/29/19 jk released per MCL SME (Maureen/Kristen) review.  9/13/19 jk updated OC semantics to use single concept for consistency with other MCL content.  2/4/19 Created for MCL - smt

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities._A substance holding another substance in solution or suspension._To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solution of water soluble glycols and resins that provide a specimen support matrix for cryostat sectioning at temperatures of -10 degrees C and below.

Concepts.definition: A solution of water soluble glycols and resins that provide a specimen support matrix for cryostat sectioning at temperatures of -10 degrees C and below.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not previously used.: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.

Concepts.definition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.
